Award.AbstractNarration:
Our research proposal concerns the interplay between Operator Theory and Function Theory in one and several variables. A particular group of problems that we propose to attack involves the generalizations to several complex variables of some of the classical moment and interpolation problems on the unit disc such as the interpolation theorem of Nevanlinna and Pick, and the moment theorems of Caratheodory and Herglotz. Other groups involve the generalization of geometric function theory to analytic varieties and the understanding of extremal mappings into the symmetrized bidisc. Research intrinsic to operator theory that we will undertake includes issues involving model theory in one variable on nonsimply connected domains in the plane and in several variables on domains other than the bidisc.

Operator Theoretic Function Theory, the particular type of mathematics that we are proposing to investigate, has direct and concrete beneﬁts for a number of areas of human endeavor. For example, the model theory aspects of our proposal all involve the generalization of the Commutant Lifting Structure which leads to an eﬃcient algorithm for the discovery of oil from acoustical data taken on the surface of the earth. Other aspects would add to the theory of Linear Matrix Inequalities. The mathematical theory of LMI?s, which currently is of great importance in several areas of engineering, is an extension of linear programming, which has made large scale resource allocation and economic prediction possible. Finally, the particular brand of function theory we propose to study, forms the mathematical core of H-inﬁnity control theory, which has been used to design control systems for fusion reactions inside Tokamaks and feedback stabilization systems for the space shuttle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In classical Newtonian physics, the position and momentum of a body are assumed to be simultaneously knowable at an instant in time. An early discovery in Quantum Mechanics was that this situation is very much different at the subatomic level. Published by Werner Heisenberg in 1927, the uncertainty principle asserts that it is impossible to simultaneously measure the present position while also measuring the momentum of a quantum particle such as an electron orbiting the nucleus of an atom.  In 1926, von Neumann laid the precise mathematical foundation for what it is that can actually be measured in the case of a subatomic particle. This seminal breakthrough involved the use of operators, i.e. linear transformations acting on infinite dimensional Hilbert spaces. Operator theory has grown over the last 85 years to become an influential and important area of research in mathematics that has had a major impact on many areas of physics and engineering. Our research during the grant period involved the development of new operator theoretic methods as well as the application of established techniques to attack a number of problems in analysis.

During the grant period substantial progress was made on developing operator theoretic tools for the study of unsolved problems in matrix theory, operator theory, the theories of functions in one and several complex variables, and the development of holomorphic function theory on analytic varieties. In particular generalizations to several complex variables of classical moment and interpolation problems on the unit disc such as refinements of the interpolation theorem of Nevanlinna and Pick, and the moment theorems of Caratheodory and Herglotz were obtained. Major progress was achieved in extending the Caratheodory-Julia Theory to several variables with a long term goal of building a geometric approach to the boundary regularity of holomorphic mappings. Model theory for operators in one variable on non-simply connected domains in the plane and in several variables on domains other than the bidisc was developed. Finally, the work of Loewner on characterizing the operator monotone functions was generalized to several variables.


Last Modified: 04/28/2012
Modified by: Jim Agler

This seminal breakthrough involved the use of operators, i.e. linear transformations acting on infinite dimensional Hilbert spaces. Operator theory has grown over the last 85 years to become an influential and important area of research in mathematics that has had a major impact on many areas of physics and engineering. Our research during the grant period involved the development of new operator theoretic methods as well as the application of established techniques to attack a number of problems in analysis. During the grant period substantial progress was made on developing operator theoretic tools for the study of unsolved problems in matrix theory, operator theory, the theories of functions in one and several complex variables, and the development of holomorphic function theory on analytic varieties. In particular generalizations to several complex variables of classical moment and interpolation problems on the unit disc such as refinements of the interpolation theorem of Nevanlinna and Pick, and the moment theorems of Caratheodory and Herglotz were obtained. Model theory for operators in one variable on non-simply connected domains in the plane and in several variables on domains other than the bidisc was developed.
